qas.question: Who found out that a shock of electricity to an exposed nerve of a dead frog caused contractions?
The tool that was invented to stain only a small fractions of neurons was called what?
What nationality was santiago Ramon y Cajal?

context: The first real progress toward a modern understanding of nervous function, though, came from the investigations of <a0_0>Luigi Galvani<a0_0/>, who discovered that a shock of static electricity applied to an exposed nerve of a dead frog could cause its leg to contract. Since that time, each major advance in understanding has followed more or less directly from the development of a new technique of investigation. Until the early years of the 20th century, the most important advances were derived from new methods for staining cells. Particularly critical was the invention of <a1_0>the Golgi stain<a1_0/>, which (when correctly used) stains only a small fraction of neurons, but stains them in their entirety, including cell body, dendrites, and axon. Without such a stain, brain tissue under a microscope appears as an impenetrable tangle of protoplasmic fibers, in which it is impossible to determine any structure. In the hands of Camillo Golgi, and especially of the <a2_0>Spanish<a2_0/> neuroanatomist Santiago Ramón y Cajal, the new stain revealed hundreds of distinct types of neurons, each with its own unique dendritic structure and pattern of connectivity.
